FacilityName: Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC - Garden City, KS Fac

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.Description:
NH3 S&H (Covered Process 1):



The Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed.  The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



This Facility stores and handles anhydrous ammonia in a single stationary pressure vessel (PV).  The process equipment includes: (1) one 30,000-gallon PV and ancillary process piping, valves, volume and pressure gauges, and cable operated emergency shutdown system.



Trained Process Operators operate the covered process which includes the: (1) overseeing the transfer of anhydrous ammonia from a commercial tanker truck to the stationary PVs; (2) monitoring of temperature, volume, and pressures during storage; and (3) transfer of anhydrous ammonia from the stationary PV to the Base Blending Process.  These operations are conducted in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Operating Procedures.  Trained personnel perform maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Mechanical Integrity Procedures.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Air actuated valves in Blender process piping; EFV and ESO at PV
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Process piping, valves, pumps, and air compressor
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Base Blending (Covered Process 2):



The Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed.  The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



The Base fertilizer product is produced by mixing anhydrous ammonia with water and other ingredients.  The process equipment is physically connected by process piping to the 30,000-gallon anhydrous ammonia Pressure Vessel (PV).  The process equipment includes: a stationary blender and ancillary process piping, valves, scale, and temperature gauges.  The blender is open top and does not have any storage capabilities for anhydrous ammonia. 



Trained Process Operators operate the covered process which includes the: (1) transfer of anhydrous ammonia, water, and other ingredients to the blender; (2) monitoring of mass and temperatures; and (3) transfer of product to storage.  These operations are conducted in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Operating Procedures.  Trained personnel perform maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Mechanical Integrity Procedures.  The fertilizer product is not subject to the RMP Rule.

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Heat exchanger C-8 and ancillary ammonia piping
_prev_prog_3.Description:
APP Blending (Covered Process 3):



The Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



Ammonium Polyphosphate (APP) fertilizer is produced by blending anhydrous ammonia with super-phosphoric acid in a reacting chamber and then mixing with water.  The process equipment consists of: (1) a 10,600-gallon commercial transport pressure vessel that is owned and operated by a an anhydrous ammonia transport company; and (2) a Mobile Pipe Reactor (MPR) that is owned and operated by an Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor (IFRC).  The MPR ancillary equipment includes transfer hoses, liquid pumps, process piping, reacting chamber, valves, pumps, evaporative cooling tower, flow meters, and pressure and temperature gauges.  The MPR does not have any storage capabilities for anhydrous ammonia. The APP product is not subject to the RMP rule.



This covered process is subject to the OSHA PSM regulations and the IFRC is responsible for the development and implementation of its PSM.  Contractor Process Operators operate the covered process which includes the: (1) transportation and set up of an anhydrous ammonia  commercial transport pressure vessel; (2) transfer of anhydrous ammonia, phosphoric acid, and water to the MPR; (3) monitoring of flows, temperatures, and pressures; and (4) transfer of APP to storage.  The IFRC is responsible for training its Operators in accordance with the IFRC PSM.  The Facility requires that the IFRC have in place and demonstrates compliance with its OSHA PSM for the MPR operations.

_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Storage tank, process piping, valves, pump, containment
_prev_prog_2.Description:
AA S&H (Covered Process 4):



The Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed.  Although the process is not subject to the OSHA PSM rules, the Facility has incorporated this process into its PSM/RMPr combined management plan.  The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



This Facility stores and handles a 23% ammonia concentrated solution in a dedicated stationary 20,300-gallon aboveground storage tank (AST) that meets the OSHA definition of a pressure vessel (i.e. > 15 psig).  The process equipment includes the AST and ancillary process piping, valves, and transfer hose.   



Trained Process Operators operate the covered process which includes the: (1) oversight of aqua ammonia transfer from the commercial tanker truck to the AST; and (2) storage of aqua ammonia in the AST.  These operations are conducted in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Operating Procedures.  Trained personnel perform maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Mechanical Integrity Procedures.

_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: air actuated valves at the blender
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Process piping, pump, valves, evaporative cooler, containment
_prev_prog_2.Description:
O-Phos Blending (Covered Process 5):



The Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed.  Although the process is not subject to the OSHA PSM rules, the Facility has incorporated this process into its PSM/RMPr combined management plan.  The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



The MAP/DAP ingredient for O-Phos is produced by blending aqua ammonia with super-phosphoric acid in a stationary pipe reactor and then mixing with water.  The process equipment consists of: (1) the 20,300-gallon AST; and (2) a Stationary Pipe Reactor (SPR).  The SPR ancillary equipment includes transfer hoses, liquid pumps, process piping, reacting chamber, valves, pumps, evaporative cooling tower, flow meters, and pressure and temperature gauges.  The SPR does not have any storage capabilities for aqua ammonia. The MAP/DAP ingredient is not subject to the RMP rule.



Trained Process Operators operate the covered process which includes the: (1) transfer of aqua ammonia, phosphoric acid, and water to the SPR; (2) monitoring of flows, temperatures, and pressures; and (3) transfer of the MAP/DAP to a mix pot where additional ingredients are added to make O-Phos.  These operations are conducted in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Operating Procedures.  Trained personnel perform maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Mechanical Integrity Procedures.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department.  Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



This EPA RMP was prepared in accordance with the requirements of the Clean Air Act ? 112(r), OSHA 29 CFR ? 1910.119, and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR ?68. The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to operations at this Facility.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC (Helena) is submitting the EPA RMP as a 5-year update.



FACILITY



The operations at this Facility consist of chemical storage and handling, blending, retail sale and distribution.  Two chemicals (i.e. anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia greater than 20% ammonia concentration) are stored and handled at quantities that exceed the regulatory threshold quantity.  Covered processes operated at this Facility include:



?    Covered Process 1: NH3 Storage and Handling

?    Covered Process 2: Base Blending

?    Covered Process 3: Ammonium Polyphosphate (APP) Blending

?    Covered Process 4: Aqua Ammonia Storage and Handling

?    Covered Process 5: O-Phos Blending

 



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for all five (5) covered processes.  The worst case scenario release assumed that all the contents in the largest single vessel were released.  For the anhydrous ammonia (i.e. representing Covered Processes 1, 2, and 3), the worst case release was modeled as if a 30,000-gallon anhydrous ammonia pressure vessel was punctured on the side at the ground level and the resulting release being a ground level horizontal jet at the maximum temperature.  For the aqua ammonia (i.e. representing Covered Processes 4 and 5), the worst case release scenario assumes that the 20,300-gallon aqua amm

onia AST failed and instantaneously spills the content into secondary containment that has a total containment capacity of 17,625 gallons when considering displacement of the other ASTs within the containment.  Therefore, some of the aqueous ammonia spills over the containment and collects onto the ground.  For purposes of determining the impacted surface area adjacent to the containment, it was assumed that the aqueous ammonia covers the impacted areas to a depth of 1 cm.  The resulting release is evaporation at the maximum temperature.



Depending on the covered process, the alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario for anhydrous ammonia assumes a release of anhydrous ammonia due to (1) rupture of a 2-inch transfer hose during a major loading or unloading operation associated with Covered Process 1; (2) rupture of a 2-inch transfer hose during transfer and blending at Covered Process 3; and (3) a leaking 2-inch process pipe during transfer and blending at Covered Process 2. The alternative scenario for Covered Process 4 assumes a release of aqua ammonia due to the rupture of a transfer hose during a transfer operation and the alternative release scenario for Covered Process 5 assumes a release of aqua ammonia due to break in the process piping between the liquid pump and Blender that occurs during a blending operation. Mitigation by engineering and administrative controls is considered in these scenarios.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Fertilizer Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility. The Fertilizer Manager is assisted by other trained personnel as directed. The Fertilizer Manager is responsible for ensuring that its employees are properly trained in the implementation of the Program 2 and 3 Accident Prevention Program elements as related to their responsibilities.  The accident prevention program elements addressed in the PSM/RMP combined program includes: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety In

formation, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



This is a non-responding Facility. The Facility has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at this Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The PSM/RMP will be updated as the Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. 



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, and 6 of EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Facility.
